Hey there sweaters. Trace and Jackie
here for DNE. Welcome Jackie. Thanks.
Deodorant, the bane of the absent-minded
person's existence. How many times have
you left the house and forgotten to put
on deodorant? All good. Gross. The
antipersperent deodorant market topped
$18 billion dollars last year. That's a
lot of pits, including yours. But do you
really know what you're slathering on
your skin? The first deodorant was
patented in 1888 with a goal to help
uptight Victorians stop worrying about
their body odor. But the odor wasn't
really their fault. It was bacteria. Let
me back up though. On your skin, you
have between 2 and 5 million sweat
glands. They come in two flavors,
echrine and apocrine. Sweat is mostly
water, but not entirely. The echrine
glands excrete primarily H2O. But the
apocrine glands located on your scalp,
in your crotch, and under your arms, put
out a thicker fluid with fatty acids,
ura, and ammonia, protein byproducts.
Once the sweat is on your skin, bacteria
go to town on it, chomping and eating up
all those proteins and pooping out
stinky chemicals like trans 3methyl 2
hexoninoic acid, which is the main
chemical that makes humans stank. Most
animal funk is used to tell other
animals different things. For example,
dogs can be trained to smell low blood
sugar and diabetics. People can tell
what you've eaten by your sweat. And
chemo signals can reveal emotions, like
if you're stressed or happy. But at some
point, we decided we wanted to cover up
the sweatyformational smell. Even before
deodorants, as we know them, people
would perfume or cologne up to cover
their distinctive odor. The first
deodorant called mum is from the late
19th century, and it allegedly used zinc
oxide, a byproduct of zinc smelting to
control bacterial growth. Fewer
bacteria, less smell. Antipersperents
were also invented in the early 1900s
and used alcohol and aluminum chloride.
The alcohol would evaporate, leaving
behind ALC3, which according to the
American Chemical Society would stop up
those echrine glands, cutting sweat
production. But remember, it's the
apocrine glands that excrete the stinky
bacteria buffet, which is why most
products combine both antipersperin and
deodorant. They plug the echrine and
keep the bacteria off the apocrine. But
like anything else, there are
consequences for messing with bacteria
in our underarms. Deodorants and
antipersperants control bacterial
populations. Some contain the now enemy
of the FDA, trickloan, an antibacterial
agent that's helping cause the rise of
superbugs. Others contain preservatives
called parabens, which if they get into
your bloodstream through razor nicks or
other open cuts, have possible
estrogen-like properties and are
connected to breast cancer tumors. All
natural deodorants cover up the little
buggers with essential oils, salts, or
alum. But whether they work depends more
on the person in their situation. But
before you say you forgot, no.
Antipersperins themselves do not cause
breast cancer. No. Nope. Nope. No. A
study of nearly 1600 people in the
journal of the National Cancer Institute
found no evidence whatsoever of
antipersperin or deodorant increasing
the risk of breast cancer. What they can
do is alter your microbiome, the
bacteria that live on us all. sometimes
helping us live healthier lives. A study
in Pier J looked at the microbiome of a
small number of people who used
deodorants and antipersperants and found
people who used antipersperants were
altering their armpit microbiome. Once
people stopped using antipersperin or
deodorant, the number of stafylocal
bacteria skyrocketed in comparison to
those who didn't use any anti peas or
dodes. I'm still working on that. I
don't know how I feel about it. What
does this mean? No idea. The study was
ridiculously tiny, but it does show that
daily hygiene can mess with our bacteria
in unknown ways. The researchers said,
quote, "We have no idea what effect, if
any, this has on our skin and on our
health. Is it beneficial? Is it
detrimental? We really don't know at
this point." As you all like to say,
more research is needed. The thing is,
you don't actually need deodorant. Some
people don't produce the chemical that
bacteria eats to make smelly byproducts.
And you'd never know if you're one of
those people unless you stop deodorizing
or if you have dry ear wax. What? Of the
2% of the human population who don't
have the gene for stinkiness, that same
gene gives people wet ear wax. So if you
have dry, flaky ear wax, you probably
don't need to be wearing deodorant. I
have to go find a cotton swab.
Look, everyone wants to smell awesome,
but what about pherommones? These
incredible chemicals allegedly tell
people all about you through the power
of smell. This is assuming humans can
sense pherommones at all. Of course,
have I incited enough excitement and
doubt? Click here to watch the video
explaining it all. Pherommones are
powerful chemical signals sent by one
organism to trigger something specific
in another. Though this is usually males
and females telling each other, "How you
doing?" They can also do other things,
though. For example, orchids signal
pollinators and ants signal friend or
foe. Are you one of those 2% who don't
need deodorant? Or do you just think you
are? Have you asked your best friend?
